questions.text:
A 26-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 20 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a routine prenatal examination. Her last pregnancy was two years ago and she gave birth to a healthy Rhesus (RhD) positive girl. Four years ago, she had a complex femoral fracture that required several blood transfusions. She has no history of sexually transmitted diseases. She has been monogamous with her husband for 5 years. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 92/min, and blood pressure is 138/82 mm Hg. Examination shows that the uterus is at the level of the umbilicus. Abdominal ultrasound shows normal fetal heart rate, movement, and anatomy. Laboratory studies show:


Blood group
A, Rh-negative



Hemoglobin
12.5 g/dL


Leukocyte count
11,000/mm3



Platelet count
345,000/mm3



Serum



 Anti-D antibody screen

negative


 Rubella IgM
negative


 Rubella IgG
negative


 Varicella IgM
negative


 Varicella IgG
positive


 STI panel
negative


Urine



Protein
trace


Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Perform a direct Coombs test at this visit. No anti-D immunoglobulin is necessary unless the patient undergoes cesarean delivery.
Administer anti-D immunoglobulin now and repeat anti-D antibody screening shortly before delivery.
Repeat anti-D antibody screening at 28 weeks' gestation. Administer anti-D immunoglobulin at 28 weeks' gestation and after delivery if the newborn is Rh(D) positive.
Repeat anti-D antibody screening at 28 weeks' gestation and administer anti-D immunoglobulin at 28 weeks' gestation. No further anti-D immunoglobulin is necessary.
No further anti-D antibody screening is necessary. Administer anti-D immunoglobulin shortly after delivery

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A direct Coombs test is performed on the newborn to diagnose HDFN but is not used to screen for anti-D antibodies in the mother. Instead, an indirect Coombs test is performed for maternal anti-D antibody screening. RhoGAM is recommended for prophylaxis against sensitization in any situation where the Rh-negative mother is exposed to Rh(D)-positive fetal red blood cells. These situations include but are not limited to, C-sections.

B) INCORRECT:

The first dose of RhoGAM is ideally administered at the beginning of the third trimester (because the risk of exposure to fetal Rh(D) antigens is highest during the third trimester) and anti-D antibody screening should be repeated before administering RhoGAM (since this medication only works in unsensitized mothers). If RhoGAM, which has a half-life of 6 weeks, is administered at this visit (20 weeks' gestation), a false-positive result for maternal sensitization will occur when the anti-D antibody screening is performed at 24–28 weeks' gestation.

C) CORRECT:

Since RhoGAM only works in unsensitized mothers, titers of anti-D antibodies should be checked (e.g., with an indirect Coombs test) prior to administration of the medication. In the United States, guidelines recommend that all Rh-negative mothers who may potentially be carrying an Rh-positive fetus undergo anti-D antibody screening at the first prenatal visit. If the first anti-D screen shows that the mother is unsensitized, she should undergo repeat screening between 24 and 28 weeks' gestation. If the anti-D screen remains negative, RhoGAM should be administered at 28 weeks' gestation (typically a single standard dose without confirmation of the fetal blood type) and, if the newborn is Rh-positive, again within 72 hours following delivery after fetomaternal hemorrhage tests to determine the dosage.

Other indications for the administration of RhoGAM include situations in which Rh-negative mothers are exposed to fetal red blood cells, e.g., invasive prenatal diagnostic or therapeutic procedures, abdominal trauma, external cephalic version, ectopic pregnancy, and bleeding during pregnancy.

D) INCORRECT:

Although this Rh-negative mother should receive an anti-D antibody screen and RhoGAM at 28 weeks' gestation, additional administration of RhoGAM may be necessary after delivery if the newborn is Rh-positive.

E) INCORRECT:

Although this patient's first anti-D antibody test was negative, titers should be checked again prior to administration of RhoGAM, as the therapy will not work in sensitized mothers. Guidelines recommend repeat anti-D antibody screening and RhoGAM administration at the end of the second trimester.
questions.hint: This Rh-negative patient is potentially carrying an Rh-positive fetus and is at risk of becoming sensitized to the Rh(D) antigen. She should undergo further screening and, if indicated, prophylaxis with anti-D immunoglobulin (RhoGAM) to prevent Rh(D) sensitization and hemolytic disease of the fetus and newborn (HDFN) in a future pregnancy with an Rh-positive fetus.

questions.text:
A 2500-g (5-lb 8-oz) female newborn is delivered at term to a 23-year-old woman gravida 2, para 2. There is copious yellow amniotic fluid. The Apgar score is 4 at both 1 and 5 minutes. The mother did not receive any prenatal care. Her first pregnancy 2 years ago was uneventful and she spontaneously delivered a healthy girl at 40 weeks' gestation. The newborn's pulse is 85/min and respirations are 20/min. She has a swollen face and abdomen, pallor, reduced muscle tone, and grimacing on stimulation. The baby is taken to the neonatal intensive care unit for further care. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
7 g/dL


Hematocrit
21%


Leukocyte count
13,000/mm3



Platelet count
200,000/mm3



Serum



 Total bilirubin
8 mg/dL


A direct antiglobulin test shows immediate agglutination of red blood cells. Which of the following are the most likely blood types of the neonate and her mother?



Neonate
Mother




Group
Rhesus
Group
Rhesus


A
B
Negative
A
Negative


B
O
Negative
A
Positive


C
AB
Positive
A
Negative


D
AB
Negative
B
Negative


E
B
Negative
O
Positive
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This combination of maternal and fetal blood groups only very rarely causes ABO incompatibility because, in patients with blood group A, anti-B antibodies are predominantly of the IgM isotype and do not cross the placenta. Moreover, HDFN due to ABO incompatibility usually has a mild disease course; this neonate's severe distress and the presence of hydrops fetalis suggest a different cause of HDFN.

B) INCORRECT:

This combination of maternal and fetal blood types would not be associated with HDFN. Neither Rhesus incompatibility nor ABO incompatibility can occur with this constellation because the child's RBCs do not carry surface antigens, which makes a reaction due to maternal alloimmunization unlikely.

C) CORRECT:

This combination is associated with Rhesus incompatibility, which may result in severe HDFN with hydrops fetalis because Rh antigen system expression on RBCs begins very early (during the embryonic period). In an Rh-negative mother and Rh-positive fetus, maternal exposure to fetal blood (most often during birth) leads to the production of maternal IgM antibodies against the Rh antigen. Over time, seroconversion to anti-Rh IgG antibodies occurs; these antibodies are able to cross the placenta in following pregnancies. In a subsequent pregnancy with another Rh-positive child, maternal anti-Rh IgG antibodies bind to the Rh antigen of fetal RBCs, marking them for destruction and resulting in HDFN. The first child of this patient's mother must have been Rh-positive.

Since Rh incompatibility may be fatal, anti-D immunoglobulin prophylaxis is administered to Rh-negative pregnant women during the 28th week of gestation of their first pregnancy. However, the mother of this patient did not receive any prenatal care and she most likely did not receive anti-D immunoglobulin prophylaxis in her first pregnancy.

D) INCORRECT:

This combination of maternal and fetal blood groups only very rarely causes ABO incompatibility because, in patients with blood group B, anti-A antibodies are predominantly of the IgM isotype and do not cross the placenta. Moreover, HDFN due to ABO incompatibility usually has a mild disease course; this neonate's severe distress and the presence of hydrops fetalis suggest a different cause of HDFN.

E) INCORRECT:

ABO incompatibility most commonly occurs in neonates with blood groups A or B born to mothers with blood group O because these mothers have anti-B and anti-A antibodies of both the IgG isotype, which can cross the placenta, and IgM isotype. ABO incompatibility may lead to HDFN but usually has a significantly milder disease course than Rh incompatibility because fetal RBCs do not fully express antigens A and B. This neonate's severe distress and hydrops fetalis would be very unlikely with ABO incompatibility.
questions.hint: This neonate presents with hydrops fetalis (swollen face and abdomen), anemia, elevated bilirubin, and a positive direct Coombs test, suggesting hemolytic disease of the fetus and newborn (HDFN).

questions.text:
A 10-hour-old male newborn is examined in the hospital nursery. He was born at 38 weeks' gestation via uncomplicated vaginal delivery and weighed 3100 g (6 lb 13 oz) at birth. The mother did not receive prenatal care. The newborn's 4-year-old brother has sickle cell disease. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows jaundice. The abdomen is nondistended and there is no hepatosplenomegaly. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
11 g/dL


Reticulocytes
9%


Leukocytes
9100/mm3



Platelets
244,000/mm3



Fetal blood group
B, Rh-negative


Serum



 Bilirubin, total

11.3 mg/dL


 Direct

0.3 mg/dL


The mother's blood group is O, Rh-negative and maternal serum studies show positive anti-Rh antibody titers. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this newborn's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hemolytic anemia and neonatal jaundice can occur with certain congenital viral infections such as congenital CMV infection and congenital rubella syndrome. The lack of routine prenatal care puts this neonate at risk for congenital viral infections but this neonate has no other evidence of these infections (e.g., low birth weight, rash, hepatosplenomegaly). Patients with congenital parvovirus B19 infection can develop anemia as a result of red cell aplasia but these patients present with reticulocytopenia and no evidence of hemolysis. While a congenital viral infection cannot be ruled out definitively, the overall presentation and laboratory findings make another diagnosis more likely.

B) INCORRECT:

A deficiency of glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) in red blood cells can cause hemolytic anemia and jaundice in affected neonates. However, symptoms usually do not occur till day 2–3 after birth. The lack of a family history of G6PD deficiency and the timing of jaundice make another diagnosis more likely.

C) INCORRECT:

RBC sickling, which can be seen in individuals with sickle cell disease (SCD), would result in hemolytic anemia. However, hemolytic anemia due to SCD generally does not develop until patients have reached 6 months of age when hemoglobin F (HbF) production decreases and hemoglobin S (HbS) production begins.

D) INCORRECT:

The presence of anti-D antibodies is characteristic of Rh incompatibility, which manifests with hemolytic anemia and jaundice in neonates. Rh incompatibility occurs in Rh-negative mothers who have developed anti-Rh antibodies from exposure to Rh-positive blood (e.g., during a prior pregnancy). Although the mother has developed anti-D antibodies due to previous exposure to Rh-positive RBCs (as is evident from her positive anti-Rh antibody titer), her son is Rh-negative and is therefore not at risk for Rh incompatibility.

E) INCORRECT:

Biliary atresia may manifest with jaundice within the first few days to weeks of life. Additional features include acholic stools and dark urine, which are not seen here. More importantly, due to the backup and reabsorption of conjugated bilirubin, direct rather than indirect hyperbilirubinemia would be expected.

F) CORRECT:

ABO incompatibility is a relatively common cause of hemolytic disease of the newborn (HDFN) affecting approx. 20% of all pregnancies and can occur even during the first pregnancy. ABO incompatibility most commonly occurs in neonates with blood groups A or B born to mothers with blood group O. Mothers with blood group O often have anti-B and anti-A antibodies even if no prior sensitization has occurred. While most of these antibodies are of the IgM isotype, which cannot pass the placenta, some are IgG antibodies, which can enter into fetal circulation during pregnancy. Since fetal RBCs do not fully express antigens A and B, these IgG antibodies only cause mild hemolysis and the direct Coombs test is usually negative or only weakly positive. Evidence of hemolysis is apparent within the first 24 hours after birth. Patients with HDFN due to ABO incompatibility do not develop hydrops fetalis or kernicterus.

See “ABO vs. Rh incompatibility” table.
questions.hint: This newborn's indirect hyperbilirubinemia and reticulocytosis are highly suggestive of a hemolytic process.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a 1-day history of lower abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding. Her last menstrual period was 6 weeks ago. She is sexually active and uses condoms inconsistently with her boyfriend. She had pelvic inflammatory disease at the age of 22 years. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 130/70 mm Hg. The abdomen is soft, and there is tenderness to palpation in the left lower quadrant with guarding but no rebound. There is scant blood in the introitus. Her serum β-human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) concentration is 1600 mIU/mL. Her blood type is O, RhD negative. Pelvic ultrasound shows a normal-appearing uterus with an empty intrauterine cavity. She is asked to return 2 days later. Her serum β-hCG concentration is now 1900 mIU/ml. Pelvic ultrasound shows an empty intrauterine cavity, a 2-cm hypoechoic lesion at the junction of the fallopian tube and uterine cavity with a thin layer of myometrium surrounding it, and no free pelvic fluid. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Administration of anti-D immunoglobulin and intramuscular methotrexate
Administration of anti-D immunoglobulin and expectant management
Administration of anti-D immunoglobulin and laparoscopy
Repeat serum β-hCG and pelvic ultrasound in 2 days
Administration of anti-D immunoglobulin and oral misoprostol

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Exploratory laparoscopy is indicated in complicated ectopic pregnancies, which manifest with severe bleeding (e.g., hemoperitoneum, vaginal bleeding), rupture (e.g., tubal rupture), and/or hemodynamic compromise. This patient is hemodynamically stable, and rupture of the fallopian tube is not suspected.

B) CORRECT:

Methotrexate is the first-line pharmacological treatment for uncomplicated ectopic pregnancies. This drug inhibits folate-dependent steps in DNA synthesis, terminating the rapidly dividing ectopic pregnancy. Because of the risk of Rh sensitization in ectopic pregnancy, anti-D immunoglobulin should be given to Rh-negative patients to prevent maternal alloimmunization and reduce the risk of Rhesus disease in future pregnancies.

C) INCORRECT:

Administration of misoprostol is appropriate for terminating an intrauterine pregnancy and can also be used to induce labor. However, misoprostol plays no role in the management of ectopic pregnancy.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient should receive anti-D immunoglobulin to prevent Rh sensitization. However, expectant management is only appropriate for patients with minimal symptoms, declining β-hCG levels, and/or no evidence of ectopic mass on pelvic ultrasound. This patient has increasing serum β-hCG levels and an ectopic mass is visible on pelvic ultrasound. A different step in management is more appropriate.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient should receive anti-D immunoglobulin to prevent Rh sensitization. However, nonurgent surgical management (e.g., laparoscopy) is typically indicated for patients with contraindications to medical therapy or in cases of unsuccessful medical treatment. A less invasive step in management is more appropriate at this point.

F) INCORRECT:

Intramuscular methotrexate is used in the treatment of uncomplicated ectopic pregnancy. However, another medication should also be administered to prevent Rh sensitization.

G) INCORRECT:

Expectant management with serial β-hCG measurements and pelvic ultrasounds is only appropriate for patients with minimal symptoms, declining β-hCG levels, and/or no evidence of ectopic mass on pelvic ultrasound. This patient has increasing serum β-hCG levels and an ectopic mass is visible on pelvic ultrasound. A different step in management is more appropriate.

H) INCORRECT:

This patient should receive anti-D immunoglobulin to prevent Rh sensitization. However, although misoprostol can be used to terminate an intrauterine pregnancy or to induce labor, it plays no role in the management of ectopic pregnancy.
questions.hint: This patient's elevated serum β-hCG concentration and pelvic ultrasound findings are consistent with interstitial pregnancy.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 38 weeks' gestation comes to the emergency department in active labor. Pregnancy and delivery of her first child were uncomplicated. The patient's blood type is Rh-negative. She received all of her prenatal care for this pregnancy including a dose of anti-D immunoglobulin at 28 weeks' gestation. Four hours after arrival, a healthy 3650-g (8-lb) female newborn is delivered. Delivery of the fetus is followed by placental retention and heavy vaginal bleeding. One hour later, the placenta is manually removed and the bleeding ceases. The mother's temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg. Examination shows blood on the vulva, the introitus, and on the medial aspect of each thigh. The neonate's blood type is Rh-positive. The rosette test is positive. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Administer a dose of anti-D immunoglobulin

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The risk of FMH is highest in the peripartum period and is further increased if the mother has antenatal or peripartum hemorrhage. The standard dose of RhoGAM to prevent Rh sensitization can neutralize approx. 15 mL of fetal RBCs (or approx. 30 mL of fetal whole blood volume). The dosage of RhoGAM that should be given in the postpartum period is determined by the amount of FMH. Therefore, fetomaternal hemorrhage tests are indicated before the administration of RhoGAM. The rosette test, which is sensitive in detecting FMH, is used as the initial screening test but it is a qualitative test. If the patient has a positive rosette test, a quantitative test such as the Kleihauer-Betke test (KB test) or flow cytometry should be performed to determine the amount of FMH and the exact dosage of RhoGAM required.

Flow cytometry is more expensive and less readily available than the KB test but is necessary if the mother has a concomitant hemoglobinopathy because the KB test is unreliable in this scenario. If for any reason, laboratory testing to detect and quantify FMH cannot be performed within 72 hours after delivery (the ideal time for RhoGAM administration), blood samples for these tests should be drawn before administering the first dose of RhoGAM.

B) INCORRECT:

In Rh(D)-negative mothers with Rh(D)-positive newborns, anti-D immunoglobulin (RhoGAM) is administered within 72 hours after delivery to prevent Rh sensitization. A single standard dose of RhoGAM can be given at 28 weeks' gestation but in the postpartum period, a different step needs to be performed first in order to determine the amount of RhoGAM that should be administered.

C) INCORRECT:

An indirect Coombs test, which can detect the presence of anti-D antibodies, is performed in Rh-negative women at the first prenatal visit and the end of the second trimester to rule out maternal sensitization before anti-D immunoglobulin (RhoGAM) is administered (since RhoGAM only works in nonsensitized women). RhoGAM has a half-life of 6 weeks and once RhoGAM is administered, as was done here, maternal anti-D antibody screening will yield a false-positive result for approx. 6–7 months. Moreover, anti-D antibody screening does not provide any information in the peripartum period about FMH.

D) INCORRECT:

An Rh-negative mother who gives birth to an Rh-positive baby is at risk for Rh sensitization. This patient requires additional management to prevent Rh sensitization.
questions.hint: In order to prevent Rh sensitization in nonsensitized Rh-negative mothers, anti-D immunoglobulin (RhoGAM) is administered at 28 weeks' gestation (typically a single standard dose without confirmation of the fetal blood type) and, if the newborn is Rh-positive, within 72 hours following delivery. The risk of Rh sensitization is proportional to the amount of fetomaternal hemorrhage (FMH).

questions.text: A 2755-g (6-lb 1-oz) baby boy is delivered at 37 weeks' gestation to a 29-year-old woman who is gravida 3, para 3. His mother received no prenatal care during her pregnancy. 12 hours after birth, he is evaluated for jaundice and lethargy. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 9.6 g/dL and a serum total bilirubin concentration of 10 mg/dL. The results of a direct Coombs test are positive. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hyposthenuria is most commonly seen in children with sickle cell disease and occurs due to chronic medullary hypoperfusion. Sickle cell disease causes hemolytic anemia, as seen in this patient, but a positive direct Coombs test is not consistent with this condition. Moreover, it would be unlikely for a newborn infant to present with functional nephropathy secondary to sickle cell disease.

B) INCORRECT:

A positive eosin-5-maleimide binding test is diagnostic of hereditary spherocytosis. The most common presentation of this condition in the neonatal period is a mildly anemic newborn with hyperbilirubinemia. However, symptomatic anemia is atypical. Moreover, hereditary spherocytosis is not an immune-mediated hemolytic condition, so a positive direct Coombs test would be unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

A petechial rash in a newborn infant would be concerning for congenital CMV infection or congenital rubella infection, both of which this infant is at risk for given the lack of prenatal care that his mother received. However, neither of these infections would be associated with a positive Coombs test.

D) CORRECT:

Hepatosplenomegaly may be seen in neonates affected by hemolytic disease of the newborn due to Rh incompatibility (more severe) or ABO incompatibility (less severe). Hepatosplenomegaly often develops as a result of hemolysis (extramedullary hematopoiesis) and can be accompanied by generalized edema, heart failure, and kernicterus. Severe cases of hemolytic disease of the newborn can manifest with hydrops fetalis.

E) INCORRECT:

Elevated urinary coproporphyrins would be expected in Rotor syndrome, a rare cause of conjugated hyperbilirubinemia in infants. Laboratory values will most often show mild hyperbilirubinemia without anemia or hemolysis. A positive direct Coombs test would not be expected.
Image Description:

Defects in the bilirubin conjugation and excretion pathways within hepatocytes result in hyperbilirubinemia. Red indicators link hereditary hyperbilirubinemias with corresponding dysfunctional enzymes and transporters.
questions.hint: A positive direct Coombs test indicates autoimmune hemolytic anemia; in this patient, the most likely cause of a positive direct Coombs test is hemolytic disease of the newborn caused by Rh incompatibility.

questions.text:
A 1-day-old girl is brought to the physician because of yellowing of her skin. She was born at 39 weeks' gestation after an uncomplicated delivery at home. She has a 4-year-old brother who is healthy and is her full sibling. Her mother received no prenatal care and has no history of serious medical illness. Physical examination of the newborn shows jaundice, hepatomegaly, and decreased muscle tone. Laboratory studies performed on the newborn show:


Hemoglobin
9.4 g/dL


Blood type
O, Rh-positive


Serum



 Bilirubin




 Total

16.3 mg/dL


 Direct

0.4 mg/dL


Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this newborn's condition?

choices.text: IgM antibody formation against A and B antigens
IgG antibody formation against D antigen

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Severe glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency (G6PD deficiency) can manifest with hemolytic anemia and hepatomegaly in affected neonates. However, symptoms usually do not occur until 3–4 days after birth and G6PD deficiency typically occurs in male patients because it is an X-linked recessive disorder.
Image Description:

Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase is the rate-limiting enzyme of the pentose phosphate pathway and oxidizes glucose-6-P to 6-phosphogluconate while reducing NADP to NADPH. NADPH is essential for converting oxidized glutathione back to its reduced form (GSH). The reduced glutathione is capable of neutralizing reactive oxygen species (e.g., hydrogen peroxide) and free radicals, thereby protecting red blood cells from oxidative damage.

In G6PD deficiency, glutathione cannot be reduced and erythrocytes become susceptible to oxidative stress, resulting in damage to the erythrocyte membrane, and thus intravascular and extravascular hemolysis.

B) INCORRECT:

The formation of antibodies against A and B antigens is the cause of hemolytic disease of the fetus and newborn (HDFN) due to ABO incompatibility. This condition can manifest with neonatal anemia, jaundice, and hepatomegaly but the risk of this condition is highest when a mother with blood group O has a fetus with blood groups A, B, or AB. This condition cannot occur if the fetus has blood group O. Moreover, unlike IgG antibodies, IgM antibodies cannot cross the placenta.

C) INCORRECT:

Biliary duct malformation, as seen in biliary atresia, can manifest with jaundice and hepatomegaly in the first few days to weeks of life. However, due to the backup and reabsorption of conjugated bilirubin, direct rather than indirect hyperbilirubinemia would be seen. Moreover, biliary duct malformation would not explain this patient's anemia.

D) INCORRECT:

Severe UDP-glucuronosyltransferase deficiency is consistent with Crigler-Najjar syndrome type 1 and can cause severe neonatal jaundice with an onset during the first 24–48 hours of life. Although this condition causes indirect hyperbilirubinemia, it would not explain this patient's anemia and hepatomegaly.

E) CORRECT:

Formation of IgG antibodies against D antigen (Rh antigen) is characteristic of Rhesus incompatibility. This complication typically occurs in Rh-negative mothers who have been exposed to Rh-positive blood during prior pregnancy or delivery. Hemolytic disease of the fetus and newborn (HDFN) will develop in a subsequent pregnancy with an Rh-positive fetus. Features of HDFN include hemolytic anemia, hepatomegaly, and neonatal jaundice, as seen in this patient.
questions.hint: This newborn presents with hepatomegaly, anemia, and jaundice due to indirect hyperbilirubinemia, suggesting a hemolytic process. In this patient, an indirect Coombs test would most likely demonstrate agglutination.

questions.text:
A 2450-g (5-lb 6-oz) male newborn delivered at term to a 26-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 2, is admitted to the neonatal intensive care unit for further care. The mother did not receive any prenatal care. Examination of the newborn shows a swollen face and abdomen. There is palpable hepatosplenomegaly. His hemoglobin concentration is 6.9 g/dL and serum bilirubin concentration is 8.1 mg/dL. A direct antiglobulin test shows immediate agglutination of red blood cells. Which of the following are the most likely blood types of the neonate and his mother?



Neonate
Mother




Group
Rhesus
Group
Rhesus

B

B
Negative
A
Negative

AB

B
Negative
